title: The Item Response Warehouse
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.3     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

Sys.setenv(REDIVIS_API_TOKEN = "AAACP+iMkCP41u+XMORLrR49kZJtscgl")

user <- redivis::user("mcfrank")
dataset <- user$dataset("item_response_warehouse")

metadata <- dataset$query("SELECT * FROM `metadata`")$to_tibble()

ojs_define(data = metadata)


ggplot(metadata, 
       aes(x = rows)) + 
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.






data







redivis = require("redivis@0.3.3")  
data2 = {
  await redivis.authorize({apiToken: "AAACP+iMkCP41u+XMORLrR49kZJtscgl"});
  return await redivis
  .user('mcfrank')
  .dataset('item_response_warehouse:6sja:next')
  .table('metadata:90m7')
  .listRows()
}
















data3 = FileAttachment("csvs/metadata.csv").csv({typed: true})







data3







Plot.plot({
  y: {grid: true},
  marks: [
    Plot.rectY(data3, Plot.binX({y: "count"}, {x: "rows"})),
    Plot.ruleY([0])
  ]
})







Plot.plot({
  grid: true,
  marks: [
    Plot.dot(data3, {x: "n_items", y: "n_participants"})
  ]
})







Plot.plot({
  grid: true,
  marks: [
    Plot.dot(transpose(data), {x: "n_items", y: "n_participants"})
  ]
})
